message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The increased laxity of the right knee joint suggests damage to the medial collateral ligament. Injury to the other options would result in different symptoms, such as an anterior drawer sign for the anterior cruciate ligament or lateral joint line tenderness for the lateral meniscus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The increased laxity of the right knee joint when the knee is flexed to 30° and an abducting force is applied to the lower leg suggests damage to the medial collateral ligament (MCL). The other options are not associated with this specific type of instability. The posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) and lateral meniscus are more commonly associated with posterior instability and rotational instability, respectively. The lateral collateral ligament (LCL) may cause varus instability.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The increased laxity of the right knee joint and the mechanism of injury suggest a possible MCL tear. The other options are less likely to cause this type of laxity with this mechanism of injury.

We refer to the Wiki article on knee ligament to help us. The physical examination finding of increased laxity with an abducting force applied to the lower leg suggests a medial collateral ligament (MCL) injury. The other options would have different physical examination findings, such as instability with rotational stress in posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) injury and increased laxity with varus stress in lateral collateral ligament (LCL) injury. Lateral meniscus injury would cause joint line tenderness and pain on flexion and rotation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The given scenario suggests a positive test for the Lachman test, which is used for diagnosing anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injuries. However, ACL is not among the answer options. Among the options, only the medial collateral ligament (MCL) stabilizes the knee during abduction, and a positive test for MCL injury is consistent with the scenario described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the examination finding suggests damage to the medial collateral ligament, which is responsible for stabilizing the knee joint against valgus stress. The other ligaments and structures listed have different functions and would likely present with different exam findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The increased laxity when an abducting force is applied suggests damage to the medial collateral ligament. The other options are not consistent with the examination finding.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The increased laxity of the right knee joint when an abducting force is applied to the lower leg suggests damage to the medial collateral ligament. Damage to the posterior cruciate ligament would result in an increased posterior drawer motion. Damage to the lateral collateral ligament would result in an increased varus stress test. Damage to the lateral meniscus would result in a positive McMurray test.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The increased laxity of the knee joint with a valgus stress test suggests damage to the medial collateral ligament (MCL). The other options involve different knee structures: the posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) controls anterior translation of the tibia, the lateral collateral ligament (LCL) controls varus stress at the knee joint, and the lateral meniscus is responsible for cushioning and stability.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The increased laxity with an abducting force applied to the lower leg suggests damage to the medial collateral ligament. The other options have different signs and symptoms associated with them.
